title: 114_s2486
content: The "Electronic Warfare Capabilities Enhancement Act of 2016" authorizes funds for the development and fielding of electromagnetic spectrum warfare systems and electronic warfare capabilities. Additionally, electronic warfare programs are included in the Rapid Acquisition Authority program. The Bob Stump National Defense Authorization Act allows for rapid acquisition of electronic warfare capabilities in urgent situations to prevent critical mission failure, loss of life, property destruction, or economic effects. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that the Department of Defense considers various procedures for electronic warfare acquisition, including rapid acquisition authority, other transactions authority, acquisition of commercial items, and procurement for experimental purposes. Electronic warfare involves military action using electromagnetic. Electronic warfare is defined as military action using electromagnetic and directed energy to control the electromagnetic spectrum or attack the enemy, including military communications and sensing operations. Amendments to title 10, United States Code, include adding electronic warfare to the definition of supplies. The curr_chunk discusses electromagnetic spectrum warfare, which involves military communications and sensing operations in the electromagnetic operational domain. SEC. 4 grants authority to the Secretary of Defense's senior electronic warfare executive to review and validate electronic warfare acquisition programs. The Joint Requirements Oversight Council can appeal for program reviews through the normal process. SEC. 5 requires the Electronic Warfare Executive Committee to report to Congress. The Electronic Warfare Executive Committee must submit a strategic plan to Congress within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The plan should include objectives related to ground and air interoperabilities, streamlining acquisition processes, efficiency of acquiring priority items, training methods in electronic warfare, and identifying capability gaps with near-peer adversaries.
